citations.narrative:
The facility uses cage cards as the form of identification for puppies under four months of age. Upon today’s inspection,
the cage card for two puppies did not include any information for the identification of the puppies, only referencing the
preventative medications the puppies had received.
Appropriate identification of dogs is necessary to meet recordkeeping requirements for inventory, disposition, transport,
and healthcare documentation. The facility must properly identify all dogs, including puppies, with an acceptable form of
identification as specified in this subpart.

The facility did not have disposition records for eleven West Highland White Terrier puppies that have been sold. In
addition, one of the acquisition records for a French Bulldog puppy was missing the required seller information.
Accurate acquisition and disposition information are necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of
animals during inspection and to properly trace their movements. The facility shall make, keep, and maintain an approved
method of documentation which fully and correctly disclose all information concerning each dog purchased or otherwise
acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported,
euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while
in his or her possession or under his or her control. The licensee must record the acquisition information on an approved
document for all puppies and ensure all required acquisition information is properly and accurately documented at all
times.

The facility is currently storing jugs of disinfectants, cleaners, and containers of paint enamel and gloss protection on
shelves in in the ‘Middle Kennel’, directly across from enclosures housing two adult dogs. In a separate kennel, one jar of
coconut oil previously used as a supplement has expired but continues to be stored with the remaining supplements
provided to the dogs at the facility. The facility was unaware of its expiration date until today’s inspection. Feeding food
items beyond its expiration date prevents the facility from ensuring that the nutritive value has been upheld and
preserved. All food items must be stored in a manner that prevents deterioration of its nutritive value and prevents
contamination. Husbandry items inappropriately stored in the same housing space with the dogs can be harmful or toxic if
ingested by the animal, or comes into contact with the animals. Substances that are toxic to the dogs but are required for
normal husbandry practices must not be stored in food storage and preparation areas, but may be stored in cabinets in
the animal areas.

The ‘Middle Kennel’ enclosure housing two adult dogs had shelter structures constructed of wooden surfaces that were
not impervious to moisture along the floor boards and adjacent baseboards. Building structures made of unsealed wood
cannot be properly cleaned or sanitized when permeable to moisture. The facility must ensure that all structures the
animals come in contact with are impervious to moisture for the respective areas of the sheltered housing facilities.

The facility’s current exercise plan does not include the frequency in which the pregnant female dogs will have
opportunities for exercise. An approved exercise plan ensures that adequate exercise opportunities are provided for the
dogs on-hand and is appropriate based on its pregnancy status and physical needs. The facility shall maintain an
appropriate exercise plan that’s approved by the attending veterinarian and available during APHIS inspections for review.

The facility’s updated program of veterinary care does not include preventative care measures for the adult dogs’ general
health needs, such as nail trims and oversight of the teeth, ears, eyes, and skin. Though the facility has a grooming
document, these specific preventative needs have not been addressed.
Following a program of veterinary care's directives for preventative care ensures the animals are adequately protected
from dangerous diseases and illnesses and safeguards their overall health status. The facility must follow the approved
program of veterinary and ensure all preventatives and sample testing are completed according to the approved
schedule.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by August 2nd 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.50(a)(2) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
The facility uses cage cards as the form of identification for puppies under four months of age. Upon today’s inspection, 
the cage card for two puppies did not include any information for the identification of the puppies, only referencing the 
preventative medications the puppies had received. 
Appropriate identification of dogs is necessary to meet recordkeeping requirements for inventory, disposition, transport, 
and healthcare documentation. The facility must properly identify all dogs, including puppies, with an acceptable form of 
identification as specified in this subpart. 
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility did not have disposition records for eleven West Highland White Terrier puppies that have been sold. In 
addition, one of the acquisition records for a French Bulldog puppy was missing the required seller information. 
Accurate acquisition and disposition information are necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of 
animals during inspection and to properly trace their movements. The facility shall make, keep, and maintain an approved 
method of documentation which fully and correctly disclose all information concerning each dog purchased or otherwise 
acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, 
euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while 
in his or her possession or under his or her control. The licensee must record the acquisition information on an approved 
document for all puppies and ensure all required acquisition information is properly and accurately documented at all 
times. 
3.1(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The facility is currently storing jugs of disinfectants, cleaners, and containers of paint enamel and gloss protection on 
shelves in in the ‘Middle Kennel’, directly across from enclosures housing two adult dogs. In a separate kennel, one jar of 
coconut oil previously used as a supplement has expired but continues to be stored with the remaining supplements 
provided to the dogs at the facility. The facility was unaware of its expiration date until today’s inspection. Feeding food 
items beyond its expiration date prevents the facility from ensuring that the nutritive value has been upheld and 
preserved. All food items must be stored in a manner that prevents deterioration of its nutritive value and prevents

contamination. Husbandry items inappropriately stored in the same housing space with the dogs can be harmful or toxic if 
ingested by the animal, or comes into contact with the animals. Substances that are toxic to the dogs but are required for 
normal husbandry practices must not be stored in food storage and preparation areas, but may be stored in cabinets in 
the animal areas. 
3.3(e)(1)(ii) 
   
Sheltered housing facilities. 
The ‘Middle Kennel’ enclosure housing two adult dogs had shelter structures constructed of wooden surfaces that were 
not impervious to moisture along the floor boards and adjacent baseboards. Building structures made of unsealed wood 
cannot be properly cleaned or sanitized when permeable to moisture. The facility must ensure that all structures the 
animals come in contact with are impervious to moisture for the respective areas of the sheltered housing facilities. 
3.8(c)(1) 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
The facility’s current exercise plan does not include the frequency in which the pregnant female dogs will have 
opportunities for exercise. An approved exercise plan ensures that adequate exercise opportunities are provided for the 
dogs on-hand and is appropriate based on its pregnancy status and physical needs. The facility shall maintain an 
appropriate exercise plan that’s approved by the attending veterinarian and available during APHIS inspections for review. 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility’s updated program of veterinary care does not include preventative care measures for the adult dogs’ general 
health needs, such as nail trims and oversight of the teeth, ears, eyes, and skin. Though the facility has a grooming 
document, these specific preventative needs have not been addressed. 
Following a program of veterinary care's directives for preventative care ensures the animals are adequately protected 
from dangerous diseases and illnesses and safeguards their overall health status. The facility must follow the approved 
program of veterinary and ensure all preventatives and sample testing are completed according to the approved 
schedule. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by August 2nd 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
